description: From Middle English teme, from Old French teme, tesme (French thème), from Latin thema, from Ancient Greek θέμα (théma), from τίθημι (títhēmi, “I put, place”), reduplicative from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to put, place, do”) (whence also English do).

entries.meaning: A subject, now especially of a talk or an artistic piece; a topic.
examples: "Had not you once a beautiful daughter, named Mary?" said the stranger."It is a heartrending question, man," said Andrew; "but certes, I had once a beloved daughter named Mary.""What became of her?" asked the stranger.Andrew shook his head, turned round, and began to move away; it was a theme that his heart could not brook.
variations on the theme of entrepreneurial resourcefulness

entries.meaning: Any of various colors, or color palettes, in which a design is offered; (graphical user interface) any of various skins for an app, affecting the visuals and perhaps other elements such as sound effects.
examples: switch to a dark theme to conserve battery power
[…]  his themes and exercises were in constant demand for what we called cogging and American students rather grandly called plagiarization.

entries.meaning: (music) The main melody of a piece of music, especially one that is the source of variations.
(film, television) A song, or a snippet of a song, that identifies a film, a TV program, a character, etc. by playing at the appropriate time.
(linguistics) thematic relation of a noun phrase to a verb.
(linguistics) Theta role in generative grammar and government and binding theory.
(linguistics) Topic, what is generally being talked about, as opposed to rheme.
A regional unit of organisation in the Byzantine empire.

verbs.description: theme (third-person singular simple present themes, present participle theming, simple past and past participle themed)

examples: We themed the birthday party around superheroes.

entries.meaning: (computing, transitive) To apply a theme to; to change the visual appearance and/or layout of (software).
